text: +1 on that. I use it mostly to see what developers are talking about right now. I've even seen someone link to one of my own articles without me having to do anything. The person made the effort to write "I'm not affiliated with these guys in any way" which shows how touchy they are about marketing. If you produce truly useful content, they'll share it anyway.

text: This was the main challenge of my previous role as a technical writer for 10 years. Granted, this was technical documentation, and the scenario was developers writing for other developers in the same industry - but nevertheless, it was too resource intensive for me go deep on every single new topic (machine learning, big data, front-end frameworks, cryptography, blah,blah blah). The experts simply had to write their own "how to" content, and I had to teach them how to do it. We developed something called the "enablement model" (stolen from "sales enablement") which equipped them with training materials and style guides. and other resources to help them create great content. That wasn't the principal problem though - it was convincing them to carve out the time to write as opposed to that super high priority feature that they needed to get out the door. I had to convince their boss as well...when I ran into the "writing is not my job" problem.

text: If you don’t provide a lot of value, you’ll be downvoted into oblivion on Reddit. It can work, but in order to drive significant traffic you need to hit the bigger subs and those are also more strict regarding self-promotion.

text: Have had some success (a.k.a get traffic and not get downvoted, haha) in very niche subreddits. Would recommend being the first person to post a comment about why you're posting, why you think it's valuable for the people there. A little extra authenticity can help people think twice before downvoting.

text:
Hey <@U0153BL0BEK> already great insights here.

For me, I give a price for a range of words. It's so hard to know where pieces will land after edits, especially if you don't know the team... how many edits etc. (Though you should talk about how many edits you will allow within scope, and how many are outside of scope). This limitation will help teams get through reviews (usually) more efficiently. But the range makes the company feel comfortable, I find, that there's wiggle room and they're not commited to one final word count.

So when I quote, it looks like
$xxx for <500 words
$xxx for 550-1000 words
$xxx 1-2000 words
and custom quote for anothing over that :slightly_smiling_face:

text: Anybody know if you can A/B test content in a main nav drop down menu with Google Optimize?

elements.text: Anybody know if you can A/B test content in a main nav drop down menu with Google Optimize?

text: What exactly do you want to test? If it’s just the link or the text you should be fine.

elements.text: What exactly do you want to test? If it’s just the link or the text you should be fine.

text: I'd like to reorder some of the options and add another one. Still possible?

elements.text: I'd like to reorder some of the options and add another one. Still possible?

text: Yup.  You would select the main navigation item and select “edit as HTML”.  then you can reorder the list items that are a part of the sub navigation and then just duplicate one of the items and add in the new text and link.

elements.text: Yup.  You would select the main navigation item and select “edit as HTML”.  then you can reorder the list items that are a part of the sub navigation and then just duplicate one of the items and add in the new text and link.

text: Just to add to this—at Unbounce, we have a team of 4 content writers, but creating lead resources usually requires support from our design, strategy, and demand gen teams. We’ve been publishing about 1 big, meaty lead gen content piece a quarter that targets one of our three core segments, based on feedback we hear from our Sales and CS teams on the types of resources customers are wanting This cadence doesn’t include webinars or our business as usual resources like blog posts, templates, etc. which are usually ungated and more frequent.

text: Curious to find out how those of you are approaching content frequency for blogging these days? Do you create a lot of blog posts per month or a handful? And what made you decide that was an appropriate number of content to publish?

text: I do 2 posts/week. The reasoning is that's as much as I can pump out a week as the only content creator on the team lol!

elements.text: I do 2 posts/week. The reasoning is that's as much as I can pump out a week as the only content creator on the team lol!

text:
2 posts a week, primarily for the reason <@UUKNSLX9P> mentioned. We have 100+ ideas, but it’s all the bandwidth I can handle until we get a contractor.

It was once a week, but that’s really not sufficient to boost organic traffic how I’d like.

elements.text: 2 posts a week, primarily for the reason

mentioned. We have 100+ ideas, but it’s all the bandwidth I can handle until we get a contractor.

It was once a week, but that’s really not sufficient to boost organic traffic how I’d like.

text: <@USDJZRL7N> It depends on the client, their goals and budget; typically 1-3 post per week. In most cases, this has proven to be the optimal frequency because 1) it brings enough topical diversity, 2) it usually allows you to strategically cover several phases of the sales funnel, 3) it gives you enough time to create traction and handle content distribution properly, 4) it creates a reading habit for the audience. Lately, a few of my clients wanted to test the employer branding content waters, so this too impacts the number of monthly posts. I would also underline the importance of content discoverability, proper site architecture and taxonomy - in case you want to publish daily. All in all, I am definitely not for mass content production. Quality over quantity, always.

elements.text: It depends on the client, their goals and budget; typically 1-3 post per week. In most cases, this has proven to be the optimal frequency because 1) it brings enough topical diversity, 2) it usually allows you to strategically cover several phases of the sales funnel, 3) it gives you enough time to create traction and handle content distribution properly, 4) it creates a reading habit for the audience. Lately, a few of my clients wanted to test the employer branding content waters, so this too impacts the number of monthly posts. I would also underline the importance of content discoverability, proper site architecture and taxonomy - in case you want to publish daily. All in all, I am definitely not for mass content production. Quality over quantity, always.

text: ^Agree with everything Mia says! We've chosen 2-3 blog posts as a result of some of our SEO and traffic research. We tested more, but we saw engagement drop and bounce rates increase. That number also happens to align with the pieces we've scheduled to promote our larger campaigns for demand gen and thought leadership, which I think speaks to Mia's comment about that number matching with the sales funnel properly.

That number also happens to align with the pieces we've scheduled to promote our larger campaigns for demand gen and thought leadership, which I think speaks to Mia's comment about that number matching with the sales funnel properly.

text:
I’m gonna play devils advocate to the above (who all give solid SEO based reasons) and say something cliche like _post when you have something worth saying_.

I see a lot of brands and people get into the trap of writing blogs to hit a quota rather than to add value, once you’re briefing a piece because you ‘need something for the newsletter’ rather than solving a customer problem it’s too late.

This is dependant on the type fo blog, but  the majority are not a publisher, but a resource centre. Think of it as having the answers specific to someones problem when they search for it. Very little of an audience are waiting for the next piece

text: How do you feel about article conclusions with the header “Conclusion”? Do you always try to get pithy/more specific or is there a place for that level of simplicity?

elements.text: How do you feel about article conclusions with the header “Conclusion”? Do you always try to get pithy/more specific or is there a place for that level of simplicity?

text:
I may be in the minority, but I don’t think an article should ever end with “conclusion” as the final h2.

Instead, the header can be adapted from any question:

• what’s next?
• how do you decide?
• what does this mean for you?
• what did we say?
• why is what we said important?
• how does this tie into the big picture?

elements.text:

text:
Favorite:
• Provide a great and thorough brief, writing guidelines, etc. 
• Accessible if needed
Least favorite:
• Changing scope when you’ve already started on the piece
• Starting to edit the piece while you’re still writing it :woman-gesturing-no:

elements.text: Favorite:
Provide a great and thorough brief, writing guidelines, etc.
Accessible if needed
Least favorite:
Changing scope when you’ve already started on the piece
Starting to edit the piece while you’re still writing it

text:
Favorite:
- They try to understand the strategy behind creating a content piece
- They're flexible with deadlines
- They let you 'own it'

Least favorites:

- Denies/lies of having a verbal agreement on something (happened thrice with me)
- Asks to completely edit it from scratch when it's not in the scope (which I don't; I fire them instead)
- Late payments

text: <@UUVC67604> Yep, quality over quantity, I agree with you. I wouldn't say it's cliche; it's actually common sense. However, not all search queries come from a user's need to solve a problem. The simple framework provided by Google sums up types of search intent pretty nicely: 1) I want to know, 2) I want to go, 3) I want to buy. For me, keyword research and competitor analysis are there primarily to better understand what the people I'm targeting search for, as well as to see what kind of content is already out there (i.e. to determine what would be the quality bar). In my experience, there is always room for telling something fresh and new if you're creative enough and prioritize users over search engines.

elements.text: Yep, quality over quantity, I agree with you. I wouldn't say it's cliche; it's actually common sense. However, not all search queries come from a user's need to solve a problem. The simple framework provided by Google sums up types of search intent pretty nicely: 1) I want to know, 2) I want to go, 3) I want to buy. For me, keyword research and competitor analysis are there primarily to better understand what the people I'm targeting search for, as well as to see what kind of content is already out there (i.e. to determine what would be the quality bar). In my experience, there is always room for telling something fresh and new if you're creative enough and prioritize users over search engines.
